articles.headline: With Builder in Bankruptcy, Buyers Are Left Out
articles.snippet: The collapse of the fabled Levitt & Sons, the first big home builder to fail in the current slump, illustrates how the real estate turmoil is spreading far beyond subprime borrowers.
articles.abstract: The collapse of the fabled Levitt & Sons, the first big home builder to fail in the current slump, illustrates how the real estate turmoil is spreading far beyond subprime borrowers.
articles.lead_paragraph: MURRELLS INLET, S.C.  Ettore and Larisa Costanzo are showing off their new house, which they love madly.

articles.headline: 4 Cameras Middling Only in Price
articles.snippet: Taking a look at improved features of midrange single-lens reflex cameras.
articles.abstract: Taking a look at improved features of midrange single-lens reflex cameras.
articles.lead_paragraph: Little silver pocket cameras are small and cheap, they take movies, and they don’t turn you into a tourist cliché by dangling from your neck.

articles.headline: Chain Said to Seek Bids for Weather Channel
articles.snippet: The Weather Channel, one of the last privately owned cable channels, is being put up for sale and could fetch $5 billion.
articles.abstract: The Weather Channel, one of the last privately owned cable channels, is being put up for sale and could fetch $5 billion.
articles.lead_paragraph: The Weather Channel, one of the last privately owned cable channels, is being put up for sale and could fetch more than $5 billion, according to people briefed on the auction. The channel and its rapidly growing Web site, weather.com, are already attracting interest from some of the biggest names in media, including NBC, a unit of General Electric; the News Corporation; and Comcast, these people said.

articles.headline: States Hesitate to Lead Change on Executions
articles.snippet: Why have states clung to an execution method with the potential to inflict pain when a simpler one is available?
articles.abstract: Why have states clung to an execution method with the potential to inflict pain when a simpler one is available?
articles.lead_paragraph: When a state panel recommended last April that Tennessee abandon the three chemicals used in executions across the nation in favor of the single drug usually used in animal euthanasia, the state’s corrections commissioner said no.

articles.headline: Iowans Hear Barrage of Final Pleas for First ’08 Votes
articles.snippet: The most sophisticated presidential campaigns that have ever been waged in Iowa — fully engaged for much of the year — ended in a flurry of old-fashioned get-out-the-vote efforts.
articles.abstract: The most sophisticated presidential campaigns that have ever been waged in Iowa — fully engaged for much of the year — ended in a flurry of old-fashioned get-out-the-vote efforts.
articles.lead_paragraph: DES MOINES  A yearlong prelude to the presidential election drew to a frenzied close on Wednesday here as Iowans absorbed a final torrent of campaign arguments before the state’s caucuses formally open the race for the White House.

articles.headline: Volatility of the Markets Carries On in 2008
articles.snippet: Oil’s $100-a-barrel price flirtation suggests that traders will see more of the escalation in energy markets that marked the final months of 2007.
articles.abstract: Oil’s $100-a-barrel price flirtation suggests that traders will see more of the escalation in energy markets that marked the final months of 2007.
articles.lead_paragraph: HOUSTON  Oil prices began the year with a volatile surge on Wednesday, briefly reaching $100 a barrel, a long-awaited milestone in an era of rapidly escalating energy demand and tightening supplies.

articles.headline: Fatigue Factor Gives Equal Time to Candidates
articles.snippet: Any candidate will attest that the epic fight now is against sleep deprivation, the gaffe-inducing monster that looms over a campaign in its final hours.
articles.abstract: Any candidate will attest that the epic fight now is against sleep deprivation, the gaffe-inducing monster that looms over a campaign in its final hours.
articles.lead_paragraph: DES MOINES  It’s the groggy, nerve-sizzling season on the trail, and forget the attack ads and last-minute scrapping. Any candidate will attest that the epic fight now is against sleep deprivation, the gaffe-inducing monster that looms over every campaign in its final hours.

articles.headline: Political Field Is Panned by Bloomberg
articles.snippet: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg suggested Wednesday that his potential presidential rivals are offering meaningless bromides rather than serious answers to the problems confronting the country.
articles.abstract: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg suggested Wednesday that his potential presidential rivals are offering meaningless bromides rather than serious answers to the problems confronting the country.
articles.lead_paragraph: With unusually dismissive language, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg offered tart assessments of his potential presidential rivals at a news conference on Wednesday, suggesting they are offering meaningless bromides rather than serious answers to the problems confronting the country.

articles.headline: Discussion of a Fed Cut Only Stirs Up Concerns About a Weak Economy
articles.snippet: Usually cheered by an impending rate cut, investors reacted to the Fed minutes with anxiety that the economy is heading toward a recession.
articles.abstract: Usually cheered by an impending rate cut, investors reacted to the Fed minutes with anxiety that the economy is heading toward a recession.
articles.lead_paragraph: Wall Street stumbled out of the blocks for the new year after oil prices surged briefly to $100 a barrel and a report pointing to a fall in manufacturing activity in December revived fears that the economy would falter in 2008.

articles.headline: Kenya, Known for Its Stability, Topples Into Post-Election Chaos
articles.snippet: Western diplomats have been putting pressure on the government and opposition to end the bloodletting.
articles.abstract: Western diplomats have been putting pressure on the government and opposition to end the bloodletting.
articles.lead_paragraph: KIAMBAA, Kenya  Daniel Kibigo said he was there, hiding in the burned cornfields nearby, as the mob gleefully stuffed mattresses in front of the church’s doors and set them on fire.
